abstract: Emine Ziyatdinova, a Crimean Tatar, has been documenting the changes in her homeland in the years since the Russian Federation annexed the Crimean peninsula from Ukraine.

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: Emine Ziyatdinova has been living through the unsettling changes in Crimea since 2014, when Russia annexed the peninsula from Ukraine and a disputed referendum approved it. She is among the minority who opposed it: She is a Crimean Tatar whose grandparents — like others of her ethnic group — had been expelled by Joseph Stalin in the 1944 and exiled to Uzbekistan. Her family returned in 1990 after Soviet authorities allowed Crimean Tatars to return in 1989, but their homecoming has proved to be a nervous, tenuous existence.
snippet: Emine Ziyatdinova, a Crimean Tatar, has been documenting the changes in her homeland in the years since the Russian Federation annexed the Crimean peninsula from Ukraine....

headline.main: A Crimean Tatar Documents Her Annexed Homeland
